title: Jenni "JWoww" Farley on Writing/Directing DEVON
description: McEric chats with reality star Jenni "JWoww" Farley on her feature-film debut as writer/director of the found-footage horror film DEVON. Read the full article on AICN Found footage horror. Do you love it? Do you hate it? Do you think it is its own genre or do you lump it in with its overarching tone - slasher, supernatural, monster, etc. Love it or hate it, the convention is here to stay, as it offers a realistic, relatable approach to horror that blurs the lines between reality, film, empathy, and voyeurism. ¬† So, when I got an email asking if I wanted to screen the feature DEVON, written and directed by Jenni ‚ÄúJWoww‚Äù Farley, I said ‚Äúof course I do!‚Äù My wife is a fan of ‚ÄúJersey Shore‚Äù and has been since day one, so I mostly did it for her, but I was also very curious what the singular star would bring to the horror pantheon. The logline read: ¬† Devon's parents never stopped searching for answers after her disappearance from a notorious asylum. Years after the incident, a mysterious website draws five adventurers to the abandoned asylum where she was last seen. Armed with cameras, they plunge into the darkness, unaware they‚Äôre filming their own descent into horror‚Äînever meant to return. ¬† ¬† I got the chance to chat with writer/director/producer Jenni ‚ÄúJWoww‚Äù Farley about jumping into a feature-length film, the serendipitous location, and her crew.¬† ¬† ¬† Eric McClanahan: Hey, Jenni! How are you? ¬† Jenni ‚ÄúJWoww‚Äù Farley: Good. Nervous.¬† ¬† EM: Nervous? Why are you nervous? ¬† JJF: I feel like this is [me] kind of starting my career over. It‚Äôs a different world, a different element. I am a superfan of horror films; I have been since I Finish the article on AICN
author: McEric

title: HIPPO'S Writer/Director Mark Rapaport Chats Video Games, Sex Talks, and Black-and-White Filmmaking
description: HIPPO'S Writer/Director Mark Rapaport Chats Video Games, Sex Talks, and Black-and-White Filmmaking Read the full article on AICN Hey, friends! Barbarella here to talk about dark comedy¬†Hippo, or more accurately to share the conversation I had with¬†Hippo‚Äôs¬†director and writer Mark Rapaport. Genuinely funny, this incredible film has the potential to achieve cult status, so long as people take a chance on this black-and-white gem and actually see it. I recommend that they do.¬†Hippo¬†stars Kimball Farley, Lilla Kizlinger, Eliza Roberts, and Eric Roberts as the narrator. It tells the story of two exceptionally different teens being raised by their mother in a somewhat isolated existence. At times, it reminds me of Yorgos Lanthimos‚Äô¬†Dogtooth, in the way that the children in¬†Hippo¬†are sheltered, while not in the same extreme way they were in the Greek film, both films make strong points about the detriment of isolation. The two would make a great double-feature, but if you want to jump on this one first,¬†Hippo¬†will be in select theaters November 8.¬† At any rate, after a night of minimal sleep due to staying out late at the Pink concert, I caught up with Mark Rapaport, and we had a fun chat about the movie. Check it out! Barbara: Why go black and white with this?¬† Mark: I've always loved classic movies, but I never thought I would make a movie in black and white until my cinematographer started taking photos of black and white, and I was like, ‚ÄúThese are so cool and good, why don't more people shoot in black and white? Maybe we should do something like that.‚Äù He was very into that. When Finish the article on AICN
author: Barbarella

title: Fun Re-Release Trailer for Zany Comedy Classic 'Hundreds of Beavers'
description: "Stop arguing. Get together. Laugh your tail off." Guess who's back?! ü¶´ü¶´ SRH has announced a December 2024 re-release of the cult classic comedy hit Hundreds of Beavers - made in Wisconsin and Michigan. The "frostbitten, anarchic slapstick action comedy" first opened in theaters in January 2024 after playing at festivals during 2023. It went on to find a big audience and become an under-the-radar genre sensation. In this 19th century, supernatural winter epic, a drunken applejack salesman must go from zero to hero and become a fur trapper by defeating hundreds of pesky beavers. "The film captures zany and anarchic energy by featuring a new gag every few seconds... A man-versus-nature narrative about overcoming the cruel and unforgiving landscape of a northeastern winter, Hundreds of Beavers is an uproarious & dynamic theatrical experience." Starring Ryland Brickson Cole Tews, Olivia Graves, Wes Tank, Doug Mancheski, and Luis Rico. If you missed the original run, tons of art house cinemas around the US will be replaying this in December. Check your local listings and get your applejack ready for yet another round of beaver madness. Here's the autumn re-release trailer for Mike Cheslik's cult classic Hundreds of Beavers, from YouTube: You [‚Ä¶]
author: Alex Billington

title: Searching for a Missing Cabin in Scary Horror 'The North Witch' Trailer
description: "Don't tell me we came all this way for nothing." Dark Star & Uncork'd Entertainment have revealed an official trailer for this indie horror film called The North Witch, the next freaky creation from indie genre filmmaker Bruce Wemple (he also made The Hangman earlier this year). Written by Anna Shields (Dawn of the Beast, Monstrous, Little Bi Peep), this chilling tale invites horror fans into an eerie, suspenseful journey set against the foreboding wilderness. üå≤ Five women embark on a search for a cabin that mysteriously went missing 60 years ago. They soon realize that watching them is a sinister, demented being. Can they survive the horrors of The North Witch, or is death the better way out? The scary horror film stars Anna Shields, Kaitlyn Lunardi, Jessy Holtermann, Ameerah Briggs, Brianna Cala, Jeremy Cohen, and LeJon Woods. The North Witch is said to be "a haunting, atmospheric experience that keeps viewers on the edge of their seats." It looks like another The Blair Witch Project remix with some freaky new twists thrown in. Here's the official trailer (+ poster) for Bruce Wemple's horror film The North Witch, from YouTube: The North Witch horror film follows five women on [‚Ä¶]
author: Alex Billington
